timeline.bodyText:
It is strange that the code invokes SET_APPLICATION_PROTOCOLS and then checks to see if it is supported. Is this because we don't know which API will work?
I see you said:

We need to use these new APIs whenever possible while still calls old versions whenever it does not break things.

But it didn't say why.
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText:
The logic of calling which API is subtle here (even myself need to think for a couple of seconds why it branches in this way).
The bottomline is, we must not invoke SET_ALPN_PROTOCOLS/SET_NPN_PROTOCOLS when it is Android R and it is using Android's Conscrypt (i.e., com.android.org.conscrypt). Otherwise, it breaks in internal version of Android R.
Other than that, we do both. This preserves compatibility for the most extent while avoid the disallowed invocation in Android R's Conscrypt.
!isPlatformSocket(sslSocket) checks if it uses Android OS Conscrypt and !SET_APPLICATION_PROTOCOLS.isSupported(sslParams) checks if it is in Android Q+. Avoid calling SET_ALPN_PROTOCOLS/SET_NPN_PROTOCOLS when both conditions are met. Otherwise, it is ok to do it.
replies.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText:
I'm concerned about the isPlatformSocket() check. That seems brittle, especially since getting this wrong will spew ugly errors. If anything, it seems we should check for the gmscore version and apply special behavior in only that case.
In general, we want to use the new API, and only the new API, everywhere it is possible. We want the old API to naturally pass out of existence and know we aren't calling it at all on newer code.

timeline.bodyText: As written, this is not working around Conscrypt. This is checking whether the API is supported in a Conscrypt-compatible way. For this to be a workaround we would need to do the does-GET_APPLICATION_PROTOCOL-throw check before this, or we would need to say "we aren't checking getApplicationProtocol as a Conscrypt workaround".
timeline.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText:
I guess you are really referring to SSLParameters#getApplicationProtocols() instead of SSLSocket#getApplicationProtocol() here. The former never throw (we aren't doing the latter during configuration). The getApplicationProtocols() check really is to see if protocols configured on SSLParameters are propagated to SSLSocket, which is only because Conscrypt on Android does this incorrectly. Normally we wouldn't need to do this. Isn't this a workaround?
I agree now it looks more like checking whether the API is supported in a Conscrypt-compatible way due to using duck-type method calls. After changing to normal Method and only do this when APIs are available, it would be clearer.
replies.author: voidzcy

replies.bodyText:
I was referring to SSLSocket.getApplicationProtocol().
An API was added in Java 9 and Android API 27 to configure ALPN. But that API is implemented by multiple implementations. So we can't assume that if the API is there that it works. I was suggesting to use SSLSocket.getApplicationProtocol() before any negotiation has occurred to see if ALPN is supported in this fashion. If the method throws UnsupportedOperationException then the implementation does not support that API and we should try other APIs. That is the way we decided to handle it in Netty.
replies.author: ejona86

replies.bodyText: I see. That was what we used to find the Conscrypt bug. Due to that bug, even the invocation of SSLSocket.getApplicationProtocol() before any negotiation has occurred does not throw UnsupportedOperationException, ALPN is still not configured correctly. Here, we are working around that bug. Consequently, this check also helps us verifying the SSLSocket is configured with ALPN, isn't it? So do we still need the does-GET_APPLICATION_PROTOCOL-throw check?
replies.author: voidzcy
